results.title: Unlikely Rebels With a Very Good Cause
results.abstract: Kate Zernike’s “The Exceptions” tells the infuriating, inspiring story of the sexism faced by female scientists at M.I.T. — and how they fought back.

multimedia.caption: Nancy Hopkins, the unlikely rebel at the head of a movement for women’s equality, at M.I.T.’s Center for Cancer Research, 1973.
Nancy Hopkins, the unlikely rebel at the head of a movement for women’s equality, at M.I.T.’s Center for Cancer Research, 1973.
Nancy Hopkins, the unlikely rebel at the head of a movement for women’s equality, at M.I.T.’s Center for Cancer Research, 1973.

results.title: Sizzling Hot Books for Cold Winter Days
results.abstract: Cozy up with one of the four new books recommended by our romance columnist.

results.title: How Well Do You Know These Page-Turners Set in Washington, D.C.?
results.abstract: Along with its memorials and monuments, the nation’s capital has been a frequent location for many spine-tingling novels. Take this week’s quiz to see how many plots and places you recognize!

results.title: Fight or Make Nice? Two Books Consider How to Listen and Be Heard.
results.abstract: “Win Every Argument,” by Mehdi Hasan, and “Say the Right Thing,” by Kenji Yoshino and David Glasgow, offer different approaches to talking to others.
des_facet: Win Every Argument: The Art of Debating, Persuading, and Public Speaking (Book)
Say the Right Thing: How to Talk About Identity, Diversity, and Justice (Book)

multimedia.caption: Eugène Criqui, a world featherweight champion, sparring with his wife in an undated photograph.
Eugène Criqui, a world featherweight champion, sparring with his wife in an undated photograph.
Eugène Criqui, a world featherweight champion, sparring with his wife in an undated photograph.

results.title: Grief, Pain and the Lingering Impact of Trauma on Black Women’s Bodies
results.abstract: In her new novel, “An Autobiography of Skin,” Lakiesha Carr tells the stories of three contemporary Black women, each struggling with different manifestations of trauma.

results.title: Rupert Holmes Can’t Read While Music Is Playing
results.abstract: “The resulting cacophony interferes with the author’s rhythms and rests,” says the musician and crime novelist, whose latest book is “Murder Your Employer.” “Like listening to Beethoven in one ear and ‘Roll Over Beethoven’ in the other.”

results.title: An Extraordinary Memoir of a Black American Boyhood
results.abstract: Joseph Earl Thomas’s remarkable debut, “Sink,” recounts the coming-of-age of a young man for whom poverty, violence, drug abuse and racism were simply facts of daily life.

multimedia.caption: Joseph Earl Thomas
Joseph Earl Thomas
Joseph Earl Thomas

results.title: QAnon and the Fear and Loathing of an American Conspiracy Theory
results.abstract: “Trust the Plan,” by Will Sommer, tracks the emergence of a bizarre movement from the wastewaters of the internet.
des_facet: Trust the Plan: The Rise of QAnon and the Conspiracy that Unhinged America (Book)

results.title: ‘Libraries, You Are My Heroes’: Readers Share Memories of a Favorite Haven
results.abstract: A photo essay celebrating the versatility of public libraries prompted an outpouring of enthusiasm from card-carrying book lovers.
results.byline: By Elisabeth Egan and Erica Ackerberg

multimedia.caption: The bookmobile has been a fixture of the library system in Cass County, Minn., since 1966. Here, a kindergarten class took stock of the offerings.

results.abstract: New books by Frances Hardinge, Annalee Newitz and Freya Marske.

results.title: 6 New Paperbacks to Read This Week
results.abstract: This week’s suggestions include a reprint of Nora Ephron’s first novel, Tolkien’s final writings on the world of “The Lord of the Rings” and more.

results.title: On Reading ‘A Wrinkle in Time’
results.abstract: Sarah Lyall discusses reading Madeleine L’Engle’s classic novel at a pivotal moment in her childhood, and the lessons she has extracted from the book throughout her life.

results.title: Letting Go of Her Ballet Dream
results.abstract: A writer confronts her “Nutcracker” childhood and the unforgiving culture that went with it.
des_facet: Don't Think, Dear: On Loving and Leaving Ballet (Book)

results.title: A Publishing Superstar Whose Memoir Shuns Glitz to Explore Private Torment
results.abstract: In “The Absent Moon,” Luiz Schwarcz, a legendary Brazilian publisher and global tastemaker, shares little of the glamorous life, focusing instead on the lifelong pain of clinical depression.
des_facet: The Absent Moon: A Memoir of a Short Childhood and a Long Depression (Book)

multimedia.caption: “When I wrote the book, I said that it was for helping others,” says Luiz Schwarcz of his memoir. “Then I realized it’s mainly for me.”
multimedia.copyright: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: “When I wrote the book, I said that it was for helping others,” says Luiz Schwarcz of his memoir. “Then I realized it’s mainly for me.”

results.title: Want to Put Something in Writing? Read These Books.
results.abstract: Getting words onto a page can be a painful process. Authors of all abilities, help is within reach!
des_facet: The Bezos Blueprint: Communication Secrets of the World's Greatest Salesman (Book)
Smart Brevity: The Power of Saying More With Less (Book)
Yours Truly: An Obituary Writer's Guide to Telling Your Story (Book)
On Writing (and Writers): A Miscellany of Advice and Opinions (Book)

results.title: Two Caldecott Medal-Winning Illustrators Tell Their Own Stories
results.abstract: Dan Santat and the late Jerry Pinkney draw from life (literally) in their memoirs for young readers.
des_facet: Just Jerry: How Drawing Shaped My Life (Book)

multimedia.caption: From “Just Jerry.”
From “Just Jerry.”
From “Just Jerry.”

results.title: Linda King Newell, Feminist Scholar of Mormon History, Dies at 82
results.abstract: Her work exploring the idea of female subservience within the church won acclaim. But it also led to her being blacklisted by Mormon leaders.
des_facet: Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)

multimedia.caption: Linda King Newell in 1985. She argued that Mormon women had once held significant power, but that they were sidelined as the church became more bureaucratic.
Linda King Newell in 1985. She argued that Mormon women had once held significant power, but that they were sidelined as the church became more bureaucratic.
Linda King Newell in 1985. She argued that Mormon women had once held significant power, but that they were sidelined as the church became more bureaucratic.

results.title: Dream Bigger With Virtual Reality! (Some Anxiety May Follow.)
results.abstract: Colin Winnette’s new novel, “Users,” examines the innovations and fears of our tech-driven age.

results.title: John Macrae III, Eclectic Publisher and Rights Champion, Dies at 91
results.abstract: In addition to having a roster of authors that included Gail Sheehy, David Levering Lewis and Lech Walesa, he spoke out for the rights of writers worldwide.
des_facet: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

multimedia.caption: John Macrae III in 1972, when he was president and publisher of E.P. Dutton. He held that post from 1968 to 1981.
John Macrae III in 1972, when he was president and publisher of E.P. Dutton. He held that post from 1968 to 1981.
John Macrae III in 1972, when he was president and publisher of E.P. Dutton. He held that post from 1968 to 1981.

results.title: 75 Years Ago, a ‘Love Letter to Manhattan’ Topped the Book Charts
results.abstract: Marcia Davenport’s novel “East Side, West Side” was edited by the legendary Max Perkins, who once told her, “Just get it down on paper, and then we’ll see what to do with it.”

results.title: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
results.abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
des_facet: Lives of the Wives: Five Literary Marriages (Book)
Against the World: Anti-Globalism and Mass Politics Between the World Wars (Book)
The Aftermath: The Last Days of the Baby Boom and the Future of Power in America (Book)
Pirate Enlightenment, or the Real Libertalia (Book)

results.title: Science Fiction Magazines Battle a Flood of Chatbot-Generated Stories
results.abstract: While the deluge has become a nuisance, the stories are easy to spot. The writing is “bad in spectacular ways,” one editor said.

multimedia.caption: The cover of Issue 193 of Clarkesworld magazine. The publication recently halted open submissions because of a large increase in work created by A.I. bots.
The cover of Issue 193 of Clarkesworld magazine. The publication recently halted open submissions because of a large increase in work created by A.I. bots.

results.title: Poem: In Defense of Nothing
results.abstract: Anyone familiar with the concept of the “1990s” might recognize the cunning of this poem’s slacker mood.
results.byline: By Peter Gizzi and Anne Boyer

results.title: 36 Hours in Miami
results.abstract: Discover the best of both new and old Miami, from a salsa club in Little Havana to a rooftop bar with striking views of downtown to Cuban American bakeries.

results.title: Jessica Chastain Returns to the Stage With Nothing to Prove
results.abstract: In a pared-down Broadway revival of “A Doll’s House,” the Oscar-winning actress doesn’t have props, period costumes or much of a set. To her surprise, she likes it.

multimedia.caption: “In the beginning, when I got all that attention so quickly,” Jessica Chastain said, “it just felt like this isn’t going to last. I felt so scared. It felt so unearned.”
multimedia.copyright: Thea Traff for The New York Times

results.title: Newly Published, From Press Freedom to the History of Ignorance
results.abstract: A selection of recently published books.

results.title: 6 Paperbacks to Read This Week
results.abstract: This week’s selection includes Richard Zenith’s biography of Fernando Pessoa, a collection of interviews with notable Black women writers and more.

results.title: Unionized HarperCollins Employees Are Back to Work After a 3-Month Strike
results.abstract: The return, after an agreement that brought a raise in pay for the lowest earners at the publisher, represented a victory to many of the more than 250 workers involved.
results.byline: By Kate Dwyer and Elizabeth A. Harris

multimedia.caption: HarperCollins is one of the five biggest publishers in the United States.
HarperCollins is one of the five biggest publishers in the United States.
HarperCollins is one of the five biggest publishers in the United States.

results.title: He Taught Americans to Cook Indian Food. Now He’s on His Final Chapter.
results.abstract: Raghavan Iyer, whose books and spirited teaching spread the cuisine, is using his last days to get familiar comfort foods to patients like himself.

multimedia.caption: As the end of his life nears, Raghavan Iyer is publishing a new book and promoting the importance of feeding patients foods that speak to their origins and conditions.
multimedia.copyright: Nate Ryan for The New York Times

results.title: The Cousins Who Ruled 19th-Century Europe, Miserably
results.abstract: “Empty Theatre,” a novel by Jac Jemc, reimagines the lives of two eccentric royals, King Ludwig II of Bavaria and Empress Elisabeth of Austria.

results.title: The Marquis de Sade’s Filthy, Pricey 40-Foot Scroll of Depravity
results.abstract: A new book by Joel Warner traces the fate of the parchment on which the infamous author wrote “120 Days of Sodom,” a trail involving scholars, aristocrats and thieves — and lots of money.

multimedia.caption: The Marquis de Sade in a drawing by Charles Amédée Philippe Van Loo, 1760.
The Marquis de Sade in a drawing by Charles Amédée Philippe Van Loo, 1760.
The Marquis de Sade in a drawing by Charles Amédée Philippe Van Loo, 1760.

results.title: An Unlikely College Bromance That Has Lasted a Lifetime
results.abstract: In his new memoir, Will Schwalbe — theater nerd and bookworm — describes the bond he continues to share with a former Navy SEAL turned eco-warrior.
des_facet: We Should Not Be Friends: The Story of a Friendship (Book)

results.title: A Poet Whose Tone Was Personal and Whose Vision Was Vast
results.abstract: “True Life,” a collection of verse by the Polish poet Adam Zagajewski, arrives in English translation almost exactly two years after his death.
